By Al Bigley
As Karl Marx once predicted, "There will always be
class struggles." And the Booster Club once a year pays
tribute to the rigid caste system at JHU.
Those who desire to attend classes on Friday afternoon, Nov. 16, may encounter some trouble—mainly be..
cause there will not be any. The annual student uprising,
Class Day, which succeeds in overthrowing organized
academic pursuits for a few hours each fall will be in
full swing on this day.
All types of activity are stimulated by this competition, and just about every type of bodily muscle will
be demonstrated by class delegates. Those who have leg
muscles will be able to leg wrestle, while those who enjoy
flexing biceps may engage in arm wrestling. Chess will
be played by those who emphasize cerebral musculature,
and card sharks can show their prowess in playing bridge.
Forensic artmen can perform in the field of debate, while
social minded gentlemen have opportunities for expression
in football, basketball, volleyball, and softball. Table
tennis matches provide competitive ground for ping pong
patriots; winged footed mercuries have their chance in.
the mile relay. For the really wild cases, tug of war,
wheelbarrow relays, and pushball can occupy their class
loyalties.
Just about every feasible avenue for expression of
inter-class animosity has been included in the lineup
of events for this historical day. From indications thus
far class spirit and spirit in general at Johnny Hops has
been running high, and this year's Class Day promises
to be one of the best in recent years. When questioned
about the plans for Class Day, Booster Club President
John "Freddit Blitz" Rogers, said: "Well yes, we . . . ah
... are ... ah .. . going to be present at Class Day—
a really big `shew'."
Class chairmen have posted various lists on bulletin
boards in the dorms and in Gilman Hall for Class members
to sign up for their respective talents in order to better
organize the competing teams
Booster club members serve as referees.
Class Day chairman Wilson Browning has outlined
the tentative schedule of events as follows:
1:30 - 2:00 Frosh vs. Sophs—jrs.. vs. Srs.—In all
sports except pushball, wheelbarrow
relay, softball throw, mile relay, tug of
war.
2:30-3:00 Fr. vs. So.—Jr. vs. Sr.—mile relay, softball throw.
3:00 Finals in above.
4:00 Tug of war, Pushball.

Economics Professor Wins Election
Late last Tuesday night Dr.
Clarence Long, Hopkins professor of political economy,
finally caught up with an elecvictory—something that
tion
eluded him in a 1958 attempt to
gain public office. Dr. Long defeated his conservative Republican opponent, Fife Symington,
and became a member-elect of
the United States House of Represntatives from one of the
twenty most populous congressional districts in the country.
In a Wednesday morning assessment of his success, the new
congressman noted that his opponent had "spent a fabulous
sum of money and even brought
in Goldwater and Eisenhower
to help." According to Dr. Long,
the Second District went "solidly for Nixon" in 1960.
The Hopkins economist won
his seat in the House by a margin of about 7,000 votes. His
last effort to win an elective
office ended with defeat in the
primary election for U.S. Sena-

M. PASNER

Limit Of Fed Payments
Lowers School Income
This article is the second in a
series which deals with the problems arising from federal grants
and contracts with institutions of
higher learning.
A balance sheet of advantages
and disadvantages resulting from
federal grants and contracts with
the University was outlined for
the News-Letter as part of this
series by Mr. Ridgely Warneld,
the Director of the Institute for
Cooperative Research.
Mr. Watheld made a distinction between two forms of federal support of research on the
Part of the University: contracts
and grants. Contracts require
more rigorous administrative details than do grants which carry
With them a relative freedom of
Use.
Advantages
Federal aid to education offers,
In general, three principal advantages to the University, according to Mr. Warfield. First of
all, it allows the University to
Pay twelve month salaries to
those faculty members engaged
in federal government supported
research. Other faculty members
are paid on the basis of an academic year.
Secondly, stipends to graduate
students from federally supported wo-rk allow them to do fundamental research which ties in
with their thesis work.
Finally, such grants and contracts make equipment available
to the University that it otherwise might not be able to afford.
Costs
The costs of such contracts
are of two types, direct and indirect. Direct costs consist of
salaries, equipments, supplies
and communication facilities
bearing a direct relation to the
carrying out of specific projects.
Indirect costs are not readily
identifiable with specific projects,
but include such things as administrative and general expenses, expenses to the physical
plant, use of library facilities,
use of additional University
owned equipment, fringe benefits
to employees involved in the
projects, etc.
To help defray these costs, the
federal government reimburses
universities for indirect costs.
Currently there is a law limiting
indirect costs on Public Health
Service grants to 15% and there
is also a statutory limit on grants
made by the agencies of the
Department of Defense allowing

The contract work involved is
being done in the Hopkins laboratories in Silver Spring, Maryland, and in Howard county. Director of the program is Dr

endowment and tuition. This
takes away not only from the
University's educational progress
but also from its own research.
The University has made a case
to the federal government for
full reimbursement of expenses,
feeling that it should be equitably paid. It hopes that sometime
in the future the federal government will pay for these added

Of Push And Pull
A move is underway to obtain more funds from
die administration for Student Activities. In its usual
officious fashion the Student Council has directed workhorse Jim MeClaine to conduct an exhaustive survey of
what campus organizations need more money and why.
A report will then be prepared, presumably by the Committee on Official Reports, and submitted to the Deans.
That improvement is necessary in the nature and
Scope of undergraduate diversions has long been a commonplace of life at Hopkins. The current approach to
the problem seems, however, to avoid the essence of
the trouble. What has been lacking even more than
money is effective and imaginative leadership.
The emphasis in student government seems to have
shifted from its proper course. Far more imagination
and creative effort is expended in the act of getting
elected to office that in doing something constructive
once this useful end is attained. This is not to belie the
sincerity of the Hopkins version of the Big Man On
Campus; real efforts to "do something" are being made.
The motivation for these efforts appears, however, to
be a little misguided. They seem to stem more from
a vague sense of duty than from genuine interest. The
prevailing attitude boils down to:"I am a leader. Leaders
are to lead. Therefore I will lead—somewhere."
The result of this had faith is that ends get lost
in means. To "do something" simply for the sake of
activity becomes a prime motivation. This is a perversion of the whole idea behind extra-curricular activities. We remind the various august personages about
our brickyard that they are supposed to enjoy what they
are doing. Unless they do they are wasting their time
and ours.
If our campus lemters have no aims more concrete
and constructive than "improvement" or "getting something done around here," why don't they relax, enjoy
their official prestige and let us alone. Everyone would
he much happier and we would he spared such spectacles
as the Student Council's solemn debate on whether or
not to enter an alligator in an intercollegiate alligator
race, the proper positioning of the garbage cans on
campus and the height of the bumps in the road.

Enter Mickey Mouse
We note in passing that an instructor in a popular
undergraduate History course has announced that exam
grades will be lowered for poor handwriting. The concept of using penmanship as a criterion of excellence is
one which properly belongs in the third grade classroom.
We hope it will be returned to its natural academic
resting place very soon.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, NOVEMBER 9, 1962

Dorm Counsellor Scores
Students'Lack of Interest
By R. E. KENNEDY, In.
Hopkins students do not seem
to know how to read or to grasp
concepts, according to Mort Rosenberg, Instructor of Political
Science Elements and counsellor
of Griffin House.
He feels, that, the basis of the
problem, is a lack of concentration as well as poor note taking
and lack of preparation before
classes. Students have a passive
attitude toward their assignments. They are not trying to
grasp the essential issues to learn
basic facts, to coordinate and
relate material. They have a
"sit back" and "feed me" attitude which explains their inability to verbalize lecture and

reading material accurately.
Mr. Rosenberg, graduate of
Harvard Law school, who finished a year's practice in New
York City before coming to Hopkins, uses a method which he
feels is the sure cure for student
passivity—the Socratic method.
If students are apathetic, says
Rosenberg, it is not entirely their
fault. The lecture method used
almost exclusively at Hopkins
fails to demand from the students. This method is adopted,
he says, because it is thought to
be more adequate for covering a
large amount of material. If,
however, the Socratic method is
used properly (the way it is used
at Harvard Law school), more
material can be covered more

thoroughly than by the lecture
method.
Socratic Teacher
The Socratic teacher must be
an authoritarian figure who has
complete control over his class,
who can lead the conversation
in the direction he wants, who
can "sut a guy up" when accuracy and pertinence requires.
Simultaneously, it demands preparation, discipline and rigid
thinking on the part of the
students.
The "Socratic class" is not a
forum where students are put on
trial. Each person is a fund of
knowledge whose participation in
the class contributes to constructing, ordering and relating
the subject matter. •
Its purpose is not to expose
or to ridicule students' ignorance,
but to induce them to think for
themselves. If someone gives a
wrong answer, the answer is
wrong not the student.
Student Interest
Students, feels Rosenberg, are
interested if someone can interest
them and stimulate their curiosity. A "thread" to connect facts
is one requisite of an interesting
class. Facts without a theme are
meaningless and a theme without
facts is groundless. Only the
teacher can supply the theme.
Mr. Rosenberg's method is a
sure check
against student
apathy and intellectual laziness.
It is also a sure check on the
tendency of some students to
become intellectuals before they
are students; of floating around
on the "third level of meaning"
before understanding or even
occasionally reading the text.

perfect couple, submitting to the

that heaven of presumably marital bliss reserved for their more
fortunate counterparts in the
Romance.

EAT, SLEEP, AND MATRICULATE
The trouble with early morning classes is that. you're too sleepy.
At late morning classes you're too hungry. At early afternoon
classes you're too logy. At late afternoon classes you're too
hungry again. The fact is—and we might as well face it -there
is no good time of day to take a class.
What shall we do then? Abandon our colleges to the ivy? I
say no! I say America did not become the hope of mankind and
the world's largest producer of butterfats and tallow by running
away from a fight!
If you're always too hungry or too sleepy for clam, then let's
hold dames when you're not too hungry or sleepy': namely, when
you're eating or sleeping.
Classes while eating are a simple matter. Just have a lecturer
lecture while the eaters eat. But watch out for noisy food. I
mean who can hear a lecturer lecture when everybody is crunch
ing celery or matzo or like that? Serve quiet stuff—like anchovy
paste on a doughnut, or steaming bowls of lamb fat.
And kindly observe silenee while lighting your post-prandial
Marlboro Cigarette. Don't be striking kitchen matches on your

Let us turn now to the problem of learning while sleeping,
First,,can it be done?
Yes, it can. Psychologists have proved that the brain Is
definitely able to assimilate information during sleep. Take, for
instance, a recent experiment conducted by a leading Eastern
university (Stanford). A small tape recorder was placed under
the pillow of the subject, a freshman named Glebe Sigafoos.
When Glebe was fast asleep, the recorder was turned on. Softly,
all through the night, it repeated three statements in Glebe's
slumbering ear:
1. Herbert Spencer lived to the age of 199 and is called "The
Founder of English Eclectic Philosophy."
2. The banana plant is not a tree but a large perennial herb.
8. The Archduke Ferdinand was assassinated in 1914 at
Sarajevo by a young nationalist named Mjilas Cvetnic, who has
been called "The Trigger of World War I."
When Glebe awoke in the morning, the psychologists said to
him, "Herbert Spencer lived to the age of 109. Whet is he
called?"
Glebe promptly replied, "Perennial Herb."
Next they asked him,"What has Mjilas Cvetnic been oalled?'!
Replied Glebe, "Perennial Serb."
Finally they said, "Is the banana plant. a tree?"
But Glebe, exhausted from the long interrogation, had fallen

At EMERSON ELECTRIC you enjoy individuality without
sacrificing security. Emerson believes in individuality, encourages
it by working philosophy and attitude. Engineers with ideas are
not only provided facilities to pursue those ideas—but are allowed
to see the idea through to finish. Consider the actual experience
of engineer Don Mertens below and decide whether or not you'd
like to know more about Emerson.

Don Mertens came to Emerson Electric three
years ago fresh from college and anxious to
explore the challenge of basic research. He
was placed in the Special Devices Group. Here
he was given problems, rather than tasks to
work on.
In an atmosphere of individual effort, supported by small-team operation, Don was able
almost immediately to demonstrate his abilities and achieve personal recognition.
His second challenge—to devise a scoring
device for a radar directed fire-control system
—proved his talents. He conceived, proposed,
developed and brought to successful completion, a magnetic scoring device. Other
projects and successes followed quickly.
Emerson's policy of allowing engineers to
range,to developtheir own individual abilities,
to carry through projects to the end, has helped
Don Mertens achieve an outstanding record.
Today, at 25, he is project engineer on a
program developing a high-resolution radar
involving advanced concepts. Don Mertens
wanted the opportunity to explore and demonstrate his personal talents. Emerson provided
that opportunity within an atmosphere of
"think freedom." Both have benefited. Is this
the kind of opportunity you want, too?

Sweep Initial Meets
Hopkins freshman debaters
have opened the 1962-63 season
With two overwhelming successes.
Their record in the first two
intercollegiate events of the year
shows nine wins and no losess.
On the afternoon of October
23, three Hopkins novice units
met and defeated three novice
units from the University of
Baltimore at that university.
This was an informal event intended to provide practice for
freshmen in debating the 1962-63
Intercollegiate debate topic: "Resolved; that the non-communist
nations of the world should form
an economic community."
Team Ties G.W.U.
On Saturday, October 27, three
Hopkins teams, each composed
of two-man units, competed in
the annual University of Maryland
Warm - up
Tournament
sponsored by the MarylandWashington Forensic Conference.
The Hopkins novice team with
Eliot Wegbriet and Kirk Tucker,
Affirmative, and Howard Read
and Toby Simon, Negative, compiled a 6-0-0 record to tie with
George Washington University
for first place in the novice
division.
In the varsity division of the
same tournament, Johns Hopkins
A finished with a 2-4 record
While Johns Hopkins .B, comPosed partially of freshmen,
broke even with a 3-3 record.

Dorm Bus Rides
To Westminster
DSRC president Neal Grove
announced Tuesday that the
council will provide bus service to
the Western Maryland game on
Saturday, Nov. 17. The service
will be "for dorm residents" and
there will be a small charge of
fifty cents or less.
Social chairman Jeff Granett
suggested that the buses would
also transport the dorm student's
dates although "none of their
dates live in the dorms."
Granitt was uncertain as to
the numbir of buses that have
been ordered but admitted under
close questioning that there
would probably be two.

As a result of an interview with freshmen on the
questions of the functions of
the housemasters and their relationship with the house residents, a shocking number were
fc-and to be in agreement on one
misconception: the house master
was the token representative of
the administration and the only
obstacle to having girls in the
dorm rooms.
Of course, this one element
immediately overshadows for
some the favorable commentary
which could be run-on from
Adams House to Jennings: "He's
a good guy .•. who lives in the
apartment which used to be our
lounge ... that lets us run the
house pretty much by ourselves
... who's busy studying but is
really concerned .. . and says

we can use his cooler .. . or
drop down to his place for a
bull session ... but doesn't give
a damn as long as you don't burn
the house down ... or walk
around naked ..."
Tutoring Helps
There are, however, particularly noteworthy instances involving extra help or tutoring in
courses besides some important
cases of "friendly advising." But,
the sampling of freshmen interviewed felt that these are no
more than isolated and therefore meaningless instances.
It is not the housemaster who
presents the obstacle to having
girls in rooms. It is, rather, an
administration policy to which
every freshman had subscribed
in accepting the responsibilities
of the Gentleman's Code. One
perceptive freshman indicated

Pall Mall Presents~

GIRL WATCHER'S GUIDE

why this concept of the "housemaster as matron" holds as much
sway as it does. He said that
the result of any imposition of
group moral standards on individuals would merely be a superficial victory.
House Master Consensus
This is the consensus of the
frosh house masters, spoken for
by Mr. Mort Rosenberg, who
sees himself and his colleagues
being set up by the administration (with all good intents) and
shot down by the freshmen
(with no reason at all save nothing else to do). The house master, as the question of girls in
dorm rooms, is symbolic. It -is
one way in which the freshman
can answer his own problem:
frustration.
Tennis in dorm rooms, lacrosse
in the hallways, water and shaving cream fights are all answers, Mr. Rosenberg says, to
the question of "How are we
going to let off some steam!"
The house master system was
inaugurated to prevent chaos
from reigning supreme in the
Freshman Dorms, but it was to
be more than this, much more.
The probable good inherent it.
the house master system has
been sapped by misconceptions
held by freshmen and the administration's vague approach.

Newspaper Fund
To Offer Awards
For Paper Work
In an effort to give promising young men an opportunity
to broaden their knowledge and
experience in journalism, The
Newspaper Fund once again is
offering $500 scholarship grants
and assistance in finding summer newspaper jobs.
The Fund provides $500 scholarship grants to the young men
who successfully complete the
work program.
The internship program is designed for thcse who are interested in newspaper work as a
career. Applicants accepted as
Newspaper Fund interns will
work in the newsrooms of participating newspapers.
Applications Available
Applications are being receiven
now on forms provided for this
purpose. They should be completed and returned promptly
to The Newspaper Fund. APPLICATION MUST BE SUBMITTED BY JANUARY 15, 1963.
After careful screening, the applicant will be notified of the
disposition of his request.
The most important part of
the application is the supplementary letter explaining the
applicant's interest in obtaining
the summer newspaper job.

By Al Bigley
As Karl Marx once predicted, "There will always be
class struggles." And the Booster Club once a year pays
tribute to the rigid caste system at JHU.
Those who desire to attend classes on Friday afternoon, Nov. 16, may encounter some trouble—mainly be..
cause there will not be any. The annual student uprising,
Class Day, which succeeds in overthrowing organized
academic pursuits for a few hours each fall will be in
full swing on this day.
All types of activity are stimulated by this competition, and just about every type of bodily muscle will
be demonstrated by class delegates. Those who have leg
muscles will be able to leg wrestle, while those who enjoy
flexing biceps may engage in arm wrestling. Chess will
be played by those who emphasize cerebral musculature,
and card sharks can show their prowess in playing bridge.
Forensic artmen can perform in the field of debate, while
social minded gentlemen have opportunities for expression
in football, basketball, volleyball, and softball. Table
tennis matches provide competitive ground for ping pong
patriots; winged footed mercuries have their chance in.
the mile relay. For the really wild cases, tug of war,
wheelbarrow relays, and pushball can occupy their class
loyalties.
Just about every feasible avenue for expression of
inter-class animosity has been included in the lineup
of events for this historical day. From indications thus
far class spirit and spirit in general at Johnny Hops has
been running high, and this year's Class Day promises
to be one of the best in recent years. When questioned
about the plans for Class Day, Booster Club President
John "Freddit Blitz" Rogers, said: "Well yes, we . . . ah
... are ... ah .. . going to be present at Class Day—
a really big `shew'."
Class chairmen have posted various lists on bulletin
boards in the dorms and in Gilman Hall for Class members
to sign up for their respective talents in order to better
organize the competing teams
Booster club members serve as referees.
Class Day chairman Wilson Browning has outlined
the tentative schedule of events as follows:
1:30 - 2:00 Frosh vs. Sophs—jrs.. vs. Srs.—In all
sports except pushball, wheelbarrow
relay, softball throw, mile relay, tug of
war.
2:30-3:00 Fr. vs. So.—Jr. vs. Sr.—mile relay, softball throw.
3:00 Finals in above.
4:00 Tug of war, Pushball.

M. PASNER

Limit Of Fed Payments
Lowers School Income
This article is the second in a
series which deals with the problems arising from federal grants
and contracts with institutions of
higher learning.
A balance sheet of advantages
and disadvantages resulting from
federal grants and contracts with
the University was outlined for
the News-Letter as part of this
series by Mr. Ridgely Warneld,
the Director of the Institute for
Cooperative Research.
Mr. Watheld made a distinction between two forms of federal support of research on the
Part of the University: contracts
and grants. Contracts require
more rigorous administrative details than do grants which carry
With them a relative freedom of
Use.
Advantages
Federal aid to education offers,
In general, three principal advantages to the University, according to Mr. Warfield. First of
all, it allows the University to
Pay twelve month salaries to
those faculty members engaged
in federal government supported
research. Other faculty members
are paid on the basis of an academic year.
Secondly, stipends to graduate
students from federally supported wo-rk allow them to do fundamental research which ties in
with their thesis work.
Finally, such grants and contracts make equipment available
to the University that it otherwise might not be able to afford.
Costs
The costs of such contracts
are of two types, direct and indirect. Direct costs consist of
salaries, equipments, supplies
and communication facilities
bearing a direct relation to the
carrying out of specific projects.
Indirect costs are not readily
identifiable with specific projects,
but include such things as administrative and general expenses, expenses to the physical
plant, use of library facilities,
use of additional University
owned equipment, fringe benefits
to employees involved in the
projects, etc.
To help defray these costs, the
federal government reimburses
universities for indirect costs.
Currently there is a law limiting
indirect costs on Public Health
Service grants to 15% and there
is also a statutory limit on grants
made by the agencies of the
Department of Defense allowing

Of Push And Pull
A move is underway to obtain more funds from
die administration for Student Activities. In its usual
officious fashion the Student Council has directed workhorse Jim MeClaine to conduct an exhaustive survey of
what campus organizations need more money and why.
A report will then be prepared, presumably by the Committee on Official Reports, and submitted to the Deans.
That improvement is necessary in the nature and
Scope of undergraduate diversions has long been a commonplace of life at Hopkins. The current approach to
the problem seems, however, to avoid the essence of
the trouble. What has been lacking even more than
money is effective and imaginative leadership.
The emphasis in student government seems to have
shifted from its proper course. Far more imagination
and creative effort is expended in the act of getting
elected to office that in doing something constructive
once this useful end is attained. This is not to belie the
sincerity of the Hopkins version of the Big Man On
Campus; real efforts to "do something" are being made.
The motivation for these efforts appears, however, to
be a little misguided. They seem to stem more from
a vague sense of duty than from genuine interest. The
prevailing attitude boils down to:"I am a leader. Leaders
are to lead. Therefore I will lead—somewhere."
The result of this had faith is that ends get lost
in means. To "do something" simply for the sake of
activity becomes a prime motivation. This is a perversion of the whole idea behind extra-curricular activities. We remind the various august personages about
our brickyard that they are supposed to enjoy what they
are doing. Unless they do they are wasting their time
and ours.
If our campus lemters have no aims more concrete
and constructive than "improvement" or "getting something done around here," why don't they relax, enjoy
their official prestige and let us alone. Everyone would
he much happier and we would he spared such spectacles
as the Student Council's solemn debate on whether or
not to enter an alligator in an intercollegiate alligator
race, the proper positioning of the garbage cans on
campus and the height of the bumps in the road.

Enter Mickey Mouse
We note in passing that an instructor in a popular
undergraduate History course has announced that exam
grades will be lowered for poor handwriting. The concept of using penmanship as a criterion of excellence is
one which properly belongs in the third grade classroom.
We hope it will be returned to its natural academic
resting place very soon.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, NOVEMBER 9, 1962

Dorm Counsellor Scores
Students'Lack of Interest
By R. E. KENNEDY, In.
Hopkins students do not seem
to know how to read or to grasp
concepts, according to Mort Rosenberg, Instructor of Political
Science Elements and counsellor
of Griffin House.
He feels, that, the basis of the
problem, is a lack of concentration as well as poor note taking
and lack of preparation before
classes. Students have a passive
attitude toward their assignments. They are not trying to
grasp the essential issues to learn
basic facts, to coordinate and
relate material. They have a
"sit back" and "feed me" attitude which explains their inability to verbalize lecture and

reading material accurately.
Mr. Rosenberg, graduate of
Harvard Law school, who finished a year's practice in New
York City before coming to Hopkins, uses a method which he
feels is the sure cure for student
passivity—the Socratic method.
If students are apathetic, says
Rosenberg, it is not entirely their
fault. The lecture method used
almost exclusively at Hopkins
fails to demand from the students. This method is adopted,
he says, because it is thought to
be more adequate for covering a
large amount of material. If,
however, the Socratic method is
used properly (the way it is used
at Harvard Law school), more
material can be covered more

Socratic Teacher
The Socratic teacher must be
an authoritarian figure who has
complete control over his class,
who can lead the conversation
in the direction he wants, who
can "sut a guy up" when accuracy and pertinence requires.
Simultaneously, it demands preparation, discipline and rigid
thinking on the part of the
students.
The "Socratic class" is not a
forum where students are put on
trial. Each person is a fund of
knowledge whose participation in
the class contributes to constructing, ordering and relating
the subject matter. •
Its purpose is not to expose
or to ridicule students' ignorance,
but to induce them to think for
themselves. If someone gives a
wrong answer, the answer is
wrong not the student.
Student Interest
Students, feels Rosenberg, are
interested if someone can interest
them and stimulate their curiosity. A "thread" to connect facts
is one requisite of an interesting
class. Facts without a theme are
meaningless and a theme without
facts is groundless. Only the
teacher can supply the theme.
Mr. Rosenberg's method is a
sure check
against student
apathy and intellectual laziness.
It is also a sure check on the
tendency of some students to
become intellectuals before they
are students; of floating around
on the "third level of meaning"
before understanding or even
occasionally reading the text.

The developmental end-roots
of the theatrical processes begun
in antiquity have seen culmination in the artful combination of
the coloratura technique of fifthcentury Athenian drama with
the exquisite simplicity of the
American love story, so classically and neatly conceived and
achieved and exuviated in Nathan

never-interest-exhausting lovedeath theme whose origins are
seen in the myth of Tristan und
Isolde (c.f.: Denis de Rougemont: L'amour et l'oecident).
All-Americanism in the dramatic arts takes the time-honored forms of Tragedy and Romance, interconnected in their
innermost structures by common,.
unifying, paraskeletal bases, determined by the depth of commitment of the author to the
ultimacy of the obstacles to the
overriding passions of the characters, which. in the case of the
nearly clicht', but, nevertheless
omnipresent eternal triangle,
(our subject matter in this little
essay), may be partial or total.
When partial. we have the
Romance, in which the perfect
couple, through the arduous conquest of the various obstacles
that stand in the path of their
consummate love, attain to that
"happiness ever after" dreamed
of by us all; and when total, we
have the Tragedy, in which the
perfect couple, submitting to the
overwhelming and fated necessity of their situation die apart,
mourning the irreparable loss of
that heaven of presumably marital bliss reserved for their more
fortunate counterparts in the
Romance.
Phaedra (pronounced Fe-dra)
marking a new and hopefully
final moment in the dramatic
dialectic touched upon already,
was conceived at the hands of
Dassin in an attempt at the perfect American Tragedy, an aim
that required the ultimate aggravation of both the passions
of the hero and heroine and the

EAT, SLEEP, AND MATRICULATE
The trouble with early morning classes is that. you're too sleepy.
At late morning classes you're too hungry. At early afternoon
classes you're too logy. At late afternoon classes you're too
hungry again. The fact is—and we might as well face it -there
is no good time of day to take a class.
What shall we do then? Abandon our colleges to the ivy? I
say no! I say America did not become the hope of mankind and
the world's largest producer of butterfats and tallow by running
away from a fight!
If you're always too hungry or too sleepy for clam, then let's
hold dames when you're not too hungry or sleepy': namely, when
you're eating or sleeping.
Classes while eating are a simple matter. Just have a lecturer
lecture while the eaters eat. But watch out for noisy food. I
mean who can hear a lecturer lecture when everybody is crunch
ing celery or matzo or like that? Serve quiet stuff—like anchovy
paste on a doughnut, or steaming bowls of lamb fat.
And kindly observe silenee while lighting your post-prandial
Marlboro Cigarette. Don't be striking kitchen matches on your

You can, if you like, permit yourself a few small shudders of

Let us turn now to the problem of learning while sleeping,
First,,can it be done?
Yes, it can. Psychologists have proved that the brain Is
definitely able to assimilate information during sleep. Take, for
instance, a recent experiment conducted by a leading Eastern
university (Stanford). A small tape recorder was placed under
the pillow of the subject, a freshman named Glebe Sigafoos.
When Glebe was fast asleep, the recorder was turned on. Softly,
all through the night, it repeated three statements in Glebe's
slumbering ear:
1. Herbert Spencer lived to the age of 199 and is called "The
Founder of English Eclectic Philosophy."
2. The banana plant is not a tree but a large perennial herb.
8. The Archduke Ferdinand was assassinated in 1914 at
Sarajevo by a young nationalist named Mjilas Cvetnic, who has
been called "The Trigger of World War I."
When Glebe awoke in the morning, the psychologists said to
him, "Herbert Spencer lived to the age of 109. Whet is he
called?"
Glebe promptly replied, "Perennial Herb."
Next they asked him,"What has Mjilas Cvetnic been oalled?'!
Replied Glebe, "Perennial Serb."
Finally they said, "Is the banana plant. a tree?"
But Glebe, exhausted from the long interrogation, had fallen

At EMERSON ELECTRIC you enjoy individuality without
sacrificing security. Emerson believes in individuality, encourages
it by working philosophy and attitude. Engineers with ideas are
not only provided facilities to pursue those ideas—but are allowed
to see the idea through to finish. Consider the actual experience
of engineer Don Mertens below and decide whether or not you'd
like to know more about Emerson.

Don Mertens came to Emerson Electric three
years ago fresh from college and anxious to
explore the challenge of basic research. He
was placed in the Special Devices Group. Here
he was given problems, rather than tasks to
work on.
In an atmosphere of individual effort, supported by small-team operation, Don was able
almost immediately to demonstrate his abilities and achieve personal recognition.
His second challenge—to devise a scoring
device for a radar directed fire-control system
—proved his talents. He conceived, proposed,
developed and brought to successful completion, a magnetic scoring device. Other
projects and successes followed quickly.
Emerson's policy of allowing engineers to
range,to developtheir own individual abilities,
to carry through projects to the end, has helped
Don Mertens achieve an outstanding record.
Today, at 25, he is project engineer on a
program developing a high-resolution radar
involving advanced concepts. Don Mertens
wanted the opportunity to explore and demonstrate his personal talents. Emerson provided
that opportunity within an atmosphere of
"think freedom." Both have benefited. Is this
the kind of opportunity you want, too?

Hopkins freshman debaters
have opened the 1962-63 season

shows nine wins and no losess.

met and defeated three novice

Baltimore at that university.

nations of the world should form
an economic community."

Hopkins teams, each composed
of two-man units, competed in
the annual University of Maryland
Warm - up
Tournament
sponsored by the MarylandWashington Forensic Conference.
The Hopkins novice team with
Eliot Wegbriet and Kirk Tucker,
Affirmative, and Howard Read
and Toby Simon, Negative, compiled a 6-0-0 record to tie with
George Washington University
for first place in the novice
division.

same tournament, Johns Hopkins
A finished with a 2-4 record
While Johns Hopkins .B, comPosed partially of freshmen,

As a result of an interview with freshmen on the
questions of the functions of
the housemasters and their relationship with the house residents, a shocking number were
fc-and to be in agreement on one
misconception: the house master
was the token representative of
the administration and the only
obstacle to having girls in the
dorm rooms.
Of course, this one element
immediately overshadows for
some the favorable commentary
which could be run-on from
Adams House to Jennings: "He's
a good guy .•. who lives in the
apartment which used to be our
lounge ... that lets us run the
house pretty much by ourselves
... who's busy studying but is
really concerned .. . and says

we can use his cooler .. . or
drop down to his place for a
bull session ... but doesn't give
a damn as long as you don't burn
the house down ... or walk
around naked ..."
Tutoring Helps
There are, however, particularly noteworthy instances involving extra help or tutoring in
courses besides some important
cases of "friendly advising." But,
the sampling of freshmen interviewed felt that these are no
more than isolated and therefore meaningless instances.
It is not the housemaster who
presents the obstacle to having
girls in rooms. It is, rather, an
administration policy to which
every freshman had subscribed
in accepting the responsibilities
of the Gentleman's Code. One
perceptive freshman indicated

why this concept of the "housemaster as matron" holds as much
sway as it does. He said that
the result of any imposition of
group moral standards on individuals would merely be a superficial victory.
House Master Consensus
This is the consensus of the
frosh house masters, spoken for
by Mr. Mort Rosenberg, who
sees himself and his colleagues
being set up by the administration (with all good intents) and
shot down by the freshmen
(with no reason at all save nothing else to do). The house master, as the question of girls in

one way in which the freshman
can answer his own problem:
frustration.
Tennis in dorm rooms, lacrosse
in the hallways, water and shaving cream fights are all answers, Mr. Rosenberg says, to
the question of "How are we
going to let off some steam!"
The house master system was
inaugurated to prevent chaos
from reigning supreme in the
Freshman Dorms, but it was to
be more than this, much more.
The probable good inherent it.
the house master system has
been sapped by misconceptions
held by freshmen and the administration's vague approach.

Newspaper Fund
To Offer Awards
For Paper Work
In an effort to give promising young men an opportunity
to broaden their knowledge and
experience in journalism, The
Newspaper Fund once again is
offering $500 scholarship grants
and assistance in finding summer newspaper jobs.
The Fund provides $500 scholarship grants to the young men
who successfully complete the
work program.
The internship program is designed for thcse who are interested in newspaper work as a
career. Applicants accepted as
Newspaper Fund interns will
work in the newsrooms of participating newspapers.
Applications Available
Applications are being receiven
now on forms provided for this
purpose. They should be completed and returned promptly
to The Newspaper Fund. APPLICATION MUST BE SUBMITTED BY JANUARY 15, 1963.
After careful screening, the applicant will be notified of the
disposition of his request.
The most important part of
the application is the supplementary letter explaining the
applicant's interest in obtaining
the summer newspaper job.
